questionListItems.title: Why does ScamShield need access to my contacts, access to make and manage phone calls, and access to send and view SMS messages?

answer.body:
ScamShield does not filter calls or messages coming from a contact saved on your phone. To do so, we require access to your contacts. We do not store your contact list on our database.


Likewise, ScamShield requires access to make and manage phone calls, and access to send and view messages to be able to spot and filter scam calls and messages from unknown contacts. 


We only store information on calls and messages from unknown contacts and which have been identified as scam to train our system, and better protect the community.

questionListItems.title: How does the Bot identify if a message is likely to be a scam or not?

answer.body: The ScamShield Bot identifies messages based on whether similar messages, numbers, and URLs have been previously reviewed and blacklisted by SPF. We also gather information from the public and check how many reports there are for similar messages. Lastly, the Bot uses a machine learning classifier to identify if a message is a scam or contains suspicious URLs.

questionListItems.title: What happens to messages and numbers that I’ve reported to the Bot?

answer.body:
When you report a scam, your reports are sent to the Singapore Police Force for review. Your report will also help others spot scams whenever they check for a scam.


When SPF blocks suspicious numbers from your report, the ScamShield App will then detect scam SMSes from these numbers, and block their calls.


We encourage you to report scams as you keep the authorities informed, and other users safe from scams.

questionListItems.title: Why can’t ScamShield automatically filter scam messages on Android devices?

answer.body:
On Android devices, we are unable to automatically move messages which ScamShield has identified as potential scams to the junk folder. This is due to the way Android is configured.

Android users instead receive a notification when they receive a potential scam SMS. They can also find a compiled list of scam SMSes they have received on the in-app Alerts History page.

questionListItems.title: I am unable to set up the app

answer.body: If you have issues with setting up the app, please follow the instructions on our website: https://www.scamshield.org.sg/setup-guide/. If you are still facing issues, do contact us through this form: https://go.gov.sg/scamshield-feedback

questionListItems.title: Who do I contact if my number was blocked by ScamShield?

answer.body: Write in to us if you feel your number might have been blocked by ScamShield here: https://go.gov.sg/scamshield-not-scam

questionListItems.title: What gets sent to the Bot when I report to the police?

answer.body:
When you submit a report to the ScamShield Bot, the SPF will be able to see only the information you have submitted through the ScamShield Bot and the time stamp at which the report was submitted. For example, here is what the SPF can see:


For Message Reports: A copy of the submitted message, the reported sender information, and the channel submitted for the report.


For Call Reports: The caller’s number or ID, info submitted about the call, where the call was received.

questionListItems.title: Can I use the Bot in other languages (such as Chinese, Tamil, or Malay)?

answer.body: At the moment, the ScamShield Bot can only reply to users in English. You can report scam messages in non-English languages, but non-English scam reports will not be as easily understandable by the reviewing team, and therefore may not provide sufficient information for determining whether scam or not. Expanding the app and Bot to other languages will depend on user feedback and demand.

questionListItems.title: Will I still be able to see the SMSes that have been filtered?

answer.body:
For iOS, filtered messages are sent to the Junk SMS folder on your phone. It is the same concept as a junk folder for your email inbox. You will still be able to see these messages if you open the folder.

For Android, a notification is sent to inform you about the scam message. The messages will remain in your inbox due to Android policy restrictions.

Please avoid clicking any links in these SMSes that have been flagged as possible scams.

questionListItems.title: Are there any privacy concerns with using the app?

answer.body:
No, both iOS and Android have strict privacy rules on what ScamShield can or cannot read.

If a message comes from a contact saved on your phone, the SMS will not be sent to ScamShield. If you have previously interacted with an unknown contact, or decided to engage an unknown contact in conversation, then ScamShield will not get to see the message either. Only messages sent by unknown persons via SMS will be read by the AI. The app also does not have any access to your location data or any personal data (because it’s not necessary!).

questionListItems.title: What happens if I delete the app? Will all my junk messages be deleted too?

answer.body:
No, the app does not delete your messages.

For iOS, the Junk SMS folder on your phone will remain with all the SMSes intact even after the app has been deleted.

For Android, all SMSes remain in your SMS folder after the app has been deleted.

questionListItems.title: Once installed, can hackers hack into my phone if the app is compromised?

answer.body: As the app does not individually identify any users, and it does not access any other data on your phone, you and your phone are not at risk even if the app is compromised.

questionListItems.title: Do I need a WiFi or data plan for the app to work?

answer.body:
You don’t need WiFi or a data plan for the app to detect scam messages. The app runs in the background to detect incoming scam text messages.

However, without WiFi or a data plan, the app will not be able to block scam calls, and will not be able to send details of reported scam messages and numbers for collation.

questionListItems.title: Will the app be able to filter spam messages from WhatsApp?

answer.body: No, the ScamShield app can only filter incoming SMSes. If you receive spam messages on other chat apps like WhatsApp, Telegram, Wechat, IMO, Viber, etc., you can forward them to us using ScamShield’s in-app reporting function. You can also use our ScamShield bot on WhatsApp to check and report any suspicious messages received on other chat apps.

questionListItems.title: Can I deactivate either the filtering of incoming phone calls or text messages function?

answer.body: Yes, either function can be deactivated at any time in your settings. Please note that this will limit the functionality of the app. To learn more, visit our setup guide: https://www.scamshield.org.sg/setup-guide/.

agency.name: ScamShield
agency.searchHint: will the app block all calls
